summary: A rare neoplasm arising from the glomus body, mainly found under the nail, on the fingertip, or in the foot. Glomus tumors are modified smooth muscle cells that control the thermoregulatory function of dermal glomus bodies. They can be benign or malignant, with malignant forms being extremely rare and often locally infiltrative.
causes: Deletions in the GLMN (glomulin) gene (familial glomangiomas)
symptoms: Lump in the neck (for head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
Sore in the mouth or throat (for head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
Sore throat that does not go away (for head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
Trouble swallowing (for head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
Hoarseness in voice (for head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
diagnosis: Tumor size of more than 2 centimeters (criterion for malignancy)
Subfascial or visceral location (criterion for malignancy)
Physical exam (for head and neck cancer)
Blood and/or urine tests (for head and neck cancer)
Imaging tests (for head and neck cancer)
treatments: Radiation therapy (for head and neck cancer)
Cancer immunotherapy (for head and neck cancer)
Targeted therapy (for head and neck cancer)
subtypes: Glomangiosarcomas arising in benign glomus tumors (GABG)
